source_payload.html:
Organization

← Previous revision Revision as of 21:55, 6 February 2026
Line 34: Line 34:


===Organization===
===Organization===
The {{lang|de|Reichsmarinamt}} comprised several departments that oversaw all of the tasks under its direction, and these grew in number and size over the course of the RMA's existence. These included (with code letters in parentheses):{{sfn|Herwig|p=22}}
⚫
The {{lang|de|Reichsmarinamt}} comprised several departments that oversaw all of the tasks under its direction. These included the Administrative Department, which coordinated the building of warships between the various involved parties, such as technical experts, naval officers, and both public and private shipyards.{{sfn|Weir|pp=88–89}} Periodic meetings were organized to monitor progress on construction programs, budgetary issues, and research efforts; these were attended by representatives from all of the other RMA departments. The Construction Department, referred to as "K" directly oversaw the design and construction of new vessels. It was, itself, divided into four branches: "KI", which covered general construction processes; "KII", which coordinated with shipyards and other machinery contractors; "KIII", which organized initial testing and [[sea trials]] of newly built ships; and "KIV", which monitored the building of ships to ensure that proper protocols were followed.{{sfn|Weir|p=24}} The Construction Department maintained an inspectorate for such supervision, and it worked in tandem with the Technical Department in that regard.{{sfn|Weir|pp=26–27}}

{{columns-start|num=5}}
*Central Department (M)
*Shipyards Department (B)
{{column}}
*Administrative Department (C)
*Weapons Department (W)
{{column}}
*Medical Department (G)
*News Bureau (N)
{{column}}
*General Navy Department (A)
*Construction Department (K)
{{column}}
*Nautical Department (H)
*Legal Department (J)
{{columns-end}}

⚫
The Administrative Department coordinated the building of warships between the various involved parties, such as technical experts, naval officers, and both public and private shipyards.{{sfn|Weir|pp=88–89}} Periodic meetings were organized to monitor progress on construction programs, budgetary issues, and research efforts; these were attended by representatives from all of the other RMA departments. The Construction Department, referred to as "K" directly oversaw the design and construction of new vessels. It was, itself, divided into four branches: "KI", which covered general construction processes; "KII", which coordinated with shipyards and other machinery contractors; "KIII", which organized initial testing and [[sea trials]] of newly built ships; and "KIV", which monitored the building of ships to ensure that proper protocols were followed.{{sfn|Weir|p=24}} The Construction Department maintained an inspectorate for such supervision, and it worked in tandem with the Technical Department in that regard.{{sfn|Weir|pp=26–27}}


Other departments included the {{lang|de|Nachrichtenbüro}} (News Bureau), which was used to disseminate pro-naval-expansion propaganda in support of larger construction programs of the Tirpitz era.{{sfn|Weir|p=22}} The Budget Department evaluated the feasibility of construction programs relative to approved budgets, and also interacted with the {{lang|de|Reichstag}} to secure the needed funding.{{sfn|Weir|p=7}} The Purchasing Office controlled the issuance of contracts to the various shipyards and component manufacturers, and it coordinated with the Construction Inspectorate to ensure that materials provided by these firms met requirements.{{sfn|Weir|pp=26–28}}
Other departments included the {{lang|de|Nachrichtenbüro}} (News Bureau), which was used to disseminate pro-naval-expansion propaganda in support of larger construction programs of the Tirpitz era.{{sfn|Weir|p=22}} The Budget Department evaluated the feasibility of construction programs relative to approved budgets, and also interacted with the {{lang|de|Reichstag}} to secure the needed funding.{{sfn|Weir|p=7}} The Purchasing Office controlled the issuance of contracts to the various shipyards and component manufacturers, and it coordinated with the Construction Inspectorate to ensure that materials provided by these firms met requirements.{{sfn|Weir|pp=26–28}}

He had already accumulated more than 60 performances since April 1, and there were still performances left in Colombia, [[Havana]], and [[Mexico]], after which he would return, without vacation, to New York to act in a few films. He would then his mother in [[Toulouse]] and would return afterwards.<ref name=hist/>

|first=Natalie |date=2014-05-01 |title=Diversion3 Acquires Transmedia Firm DJ2 |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/business/digital/diversion3-acquires-transmedia-firm-dj2-700527/ game studio [[Compulsion Games]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/we-happy-few-videogame-movie-adaptation-1202020558|title='We Happy Few' Videogame Getting Movie (magazine)|Variety]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170401125913/http://variety.com/2017/film/news/we-happy-few-videogame-movie-adaptation-1202020558/|archive-date=1 April 2017|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> On June 2017, dj2 Entertainment announced about a television adaptation to ''[[Little Nightmares]]'' with [[Anthony and Joe Russo]] developing and executive producing the series with ''[[Coraline (film)|Coraline]]'' director [[Henry Selick]] at the helm to direct the pilot and other episodes.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/russo-brothers-adapting-video-game-little-nightmares-tv-1012736|title=The Russo Brothers Adapting Video Game 'Little Nightmares' for TV (Exclusive)|last=Kit|first=Borys|magazine=The Hollywood Reporter|date=12 June 2017|access-date=12 June 2017}}</ref> In June 2020, dj2 Entertainment have partnered up with company ZA/UM to produce and develop a television series based on their game ''[[Disco Elysium]]''.<ref name=Dj2DE>{{Cite web |last=Otterson |first=Joe |date=26 June 2020 |title='Disco Elysium' TV Series Adaptation in the Works From 'Sonic the Hedgehog' Producer |url=https://variety.com/2020/tv/news/disco-elysium-tv-series-1234690455/ |access-date=1 October 2022 |website=[[Variety (website)|Variety]] |archive-date=28 June == Held various positions in the diplomatic service <ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-04-27 |title=Minister of Foreign Affairs and Expatriates |url=https://www.mofa-ye.org/Pages/minister-of-foreign-affairs-and-expatriates/ |access-date=2024-10-13 |website=Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Expatriates |language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=اليمني |first=المشهد |date=2018-07-03 |title=من هو شايع الزنداني السفير الجديد لدى السعودية ؟ .. (سيرة ذاتية ) {{!}} المشهد اليمني |url=http://www.almashhad-alyemeni.com/64033 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180703075402/http://www.almashhad-alyemeni.com/64033 |archive-date=2018-07-03 |access-date=2025-08-01 |work=المشهد اليمني |language=ar-AR}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |title=“السيرة الذاتية” لوزير الخارجية اليمني الجديد الذي اصدر الرئيس العليمي قرار تعيينه ..! |url=https://news.sahafaa.net/show170327595.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240328005750/https://news.sahafaa.net/show170327595.html |archive-date=2024-03-28 |access-date=2025-08-01 |language=ar}}</ref> ==

* Extraordinary [[Ambassador]] and Plenipotentiary to the [[Saudi Arabia|Kingdom of Saudi Arabia]] – Permanent Representative of Yemen to the [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation|Organization of Islamic Cooperation]], [[2017]]-[[2024]]
* Extraordinary [[Ambassador]] and [[Plenipotentiary]] to the [[Jordan|Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan]], [[2010]]-[[2015]]
* Extraordinary [[Ambassador]] and [[Plenipotentiary]] to the [[Italy|Italian Republic]] – Non-resident Ambassador to [[Greece]], [[Serbia]], [[Albania]], [[San Marino]], [[2005]]-[[2010]]
* [[Permanent representative|Permanent Representative]] of the [[Yemen|Republic of Yemen]] to the [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] of the [[United Nations]] ([[Food and Agriculture Organization|FAO]]), [[2008]]-[[2010]]
* Ambassador – Counselor of the Permanent Delegation of the Republic of [[Yemen]] to the [[United Nations]] – [[Geneva]], [[1994]]-[[1997]]

* [[Ambassador|Extraordinary Ambassador]] and [[Plenipotentiary]] to the [[United Kingdom]] and [[Northern Ireland]], [[1991]]-[[1994]]

* Vice [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Yemen)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] for [[Yemen|the Republic of Yemen]], 1990-1991 (Minister rank)
* Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs – [[Aden]], [[1986]]-[[1990]]
* [[Chargé d'affaires|Chargé d’Affaires]] at the [[Diplomatic mission|Embassy]] in [[Baghdad]], [[1981]]-[[1982]]
* [[Lecturer]] at the [[University of Aden]], [[1978]]-[[1981]]

'''Karl Loewenstein''' (November 9, 1891 in [[Munich]] – July 10, 1973 in [[Heidelberg]]) was a German [[lawyer]] and [[political science|political scientist]], regarded as one of the prominent figures of [[Constitutional law]] in the twentieth century.
'''Karl Loewenstein''' (November 9, 1891 in [[Munich]] – July 10, 1973 in [[Heidelberg]]) was a German [[lawyer]] and [[political science|political scientist]], regarded as one of the prominent figures of [[constitutional law]] in the twentieth century.


His research and investigations into the typology of the different constitutions have had some impact on the Western constitutional thought. Loewenstein is credited with establishing the theoretical foundations of [[militant democracy]] to battle anti-democratic mass movements.

'''Rootstock Software''' is an enterprise software company that develops cloud-based enterprise resource planning (ERP) software for product-based companies, such as manufacturers, distributors, and supply chain organizations.<ref>{{cite news |title=It’s Not All About ChatGPT. '''Rootstock Software''' is a software company based in San Ramon, California.<ref>{{cite news |title=It’s Not All About ChatGPT. Less Flashy Business Software Draws Investors, Too |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/its-not-all-about-chatgpt-less-flashy-business-software-draws-investors-too-da502abc |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=2023-06-09}}</ref> The company develops cloud-based enterprise resource planning (ERP) software.<ref>{{cite news |title=It’s Not All About ChatGPT. Less Flashy Business Software Draws Investors, Too |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/its-not-all-about-chatgpt-less-flashy-business-software-draws-investors-too-da502abc |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=2023-06-09}}</ref> Its ERP software is built on the Salesforce platform and is used by manufacturers and other product-based businesses.<ref>{{cite web |title=Rootstock Cloud ERP Plus Salesforce Platform Supports Users Effectively |url=https://www3.technologyevaluation.com/research/article/rootstock-cloud-erp-plus-salesforce-platform-supports-users-effectively.html |website=Technology Evaluation Centers}}</ref>


== History ==
== History ==


Rootstock Software was launched in 2008 and was founded by Pat Garrehy with a focus on delivering cloud-based ERP software tailored specifically to product-based organizations.<ref>{{cite web |title=Rootstock ERP Overview |url=https://www.top10erp.org/products/rootstock |website=Top10ERP}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Rootstock Company Profile |url=https://tracxn.com/d/companies/rootstock/__BKjI_3ZGc3KRQlPc2U-BEKI-rncN8ya75VwzpbZJDs0 |website=Tracxn}}</ref> From its early development, the company positioned its platform as a manufacturing-centric alternative to general-purpose ERP systems, emphasizing native deployment on the Salesforce platform and integration across sales, operations, and finance.<ref>{{cite web |title=Change is in the air for cloud ERP vendor Rootstock – here’s why |url=https://diginomica.com/change-air-cloud-erp-vendor-rootstock-heres-why |website=Diginomica |date=2022}}</ref>
Rootstock Software was founded in 2008 by Pat Garrehy.<ref>{{cite web |title=Rootstock ERP Overview |url=https://www.top10erp.org/products/rootstock |website=Top10ERP}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Rootstock Company Profile |url=https://tracxn.com/d/companies/rootstock/__BKjI_3ZGc3KRQlPc2U-BEKI-rncN8ya75VwzpbZJDs0 |website=Tracxn}}</ref> The company develops cloud-based enterprise resource planning (ERP) software built on the Salesforce platform, with functionality spanning manufacturing, finance, and other operational areas.<ref>{{cite web |title=Rootstock Cloud ERP Plus Salesforce Platform Supports Users Effectively |url=https://www3.technologyevaluation.com/research/article/rootstock-cloud-erp-plus-salesforce-platform-supports-users-effectively.html |website=Technology Evaluation Centers}}</ref>


=== Acquisitions and strategic expansion ===
=== Acquisitions and strategic expansion ===


In 2018, Rootstock acquired Kenandy, a cloud ERP provider built on the Salesforce platform.<ref>{{cite web |title=Digital Transformation Digest: Rootstock Buys Kenandy in Cloud ERP Consolidation |url=https://www.constellationr.com/blog-news/insights/digital-transformation-digest-rootstock-buys-kenandy-cloud-erp-consolidation |website=Constellation Research |date=2018}}</ref> Industry analysts characterized the acquisition as part of broader consolidation within the cloud manufacturing ERP market.
In 2018, Rootstock acquired Kenandy, a cloud ERP provider built on the Salesforce platform.<ref>{{cite web |title=Digital Transformation Digest: Rootstock Buys Kenandy in Cloud ERP Consolidation |url=https://www.constellationr.com/blog-news/insights/digital-transformation-digest-rootstock-buys-kenandy-cloud-erp-consolidation |website=Constellation Research |date=2018}}</ref>


In 2025, Rootstock expanded its services capabilities through the acquisition of Praxis Solutions, a professional services and ERP implementation firm.<ref>{{cite web |title=Gryphon-backed Rootstock Software adds on Praxis Solutions |url=https://www.pehub.com/gryphon-backed-rootstock-software-adds-on-praxis-solutions/ |website=PE Hub |date=2025}}</ref> The acquisition enhanced Rootstock’s ability to deliver ERP implementation, advisory, and ongoing customer services.
In 2025, Rootstock expanded its services capabilities through the acquisition of Praxis Solutions, a professional services and ERP implementation firm.<ref>{{cite web |title=Gryphon-backed Rootstock Software adds on Praxis Solutions |url=https://www.pehub.com/gryphon-backed-rootstock-software-adds-on-praxis-solutions/ |website=PE Hub |date=2025}}</ref>

In December 2025, Rootstock launched '''Rootstock Managed Services''', a managed services offering designed to provide turnkey administration, optimization, and operational support for ERP customers.<ref>{{cite web |title=Rootstock Software adds ERP managed service |url=https://www.enterprisetimes.co.uk/2025/12/10/rootstock-software-adds-erp-managed-service/ |website=Enterprise Times |date=2025-12-10}}</ref>
In December 2025, Rootstock launched '''Rootstock Managed Services''', a managed services offering designed to provide ERP administration, optimization, and operational services for customers.<ref>{{cite web |title=Rootstock Software adds ERP managed service |url=https://www.enterprisetimes.co.uk/2025/12/10/rootstock-software-adds-erp-managed-service/ |website=Enterprise Times |date=2025-12-10}}</ref>

The ERP solution natively connects with Agentforce Sales (formerly Salesforce Sales Cloud), Agentforce Service (formerly Service Cloud), and Agentforce Manufacturing (formerly Manufacturing Cloud), as well as third-party applications available through the Salesforce AppExchange ecosystem.<ref>{{cite web |title=Rootstock makes life easier for manufacturing operations with new digital agent |url=https://www.enterprisetimes.co.uk/2025/07/22/rootstock-makes-life-easier-for-manufacturing-operations-with-new-digital-agent/ |website=Enterprise Times |date=2025-07-22}}</ref>


In addition to core ERP functionality, Rootstock has introduced AI-enabled capabilities, including digital agents designed to automate workflows, surface insights, and support decision-making across manufacturing and financial processes.<ref>{{cite web |title=Rootstock makes life easier for manufacturing operations with new digital agent |url=https://www.enterprisetimes.co.uk/2025/07/22/rootstock-makes-life-easier-for-manufacturing-operations-with-new-digital-agent/ |website=Enterprise Times |date=2025-07-22}}</ref>

== Market position and reception ==
== Market position and reception ==

In the SMB ERP Technology Value Matrix published by Nucleus Research, Rootstock was named a '''Leader'''.<ref>{{cite web |title=SMB ERP Technology Value Matrix 2025 |url=https://nucleusresearch.com/research/single/smb-erp-technology-value-matrix-2025/ |website=Nucleus Research |date=2025}}</ref>
In the SMB (small to mid-size business) ERP Technology Value Matrix published by Nucleus Research, Rootstock was named a '''Leader'''.<ref>{{cite web |title=SMB ERP Technology Value Matrix 2025 |url=https://nucleusresearch.com/research/single/smb-erp-technology-value-matrix-2025/ |website=Nucleus Research |date=2025}}</ref>

== Customers and adoption ==

==Plot==
==Plot==
[[File:Atlantic (1929).webm|thumb|thumbtime=5|''Atlantic'' (1929)]]
[[File:Atlantic (1929).webm|thumb|thumbtime=5|''Atlantic'' (1929)]]
''Atlantic'' is a drama film based on the sinking of the {{RMS|Titanic}} and set aboard a fictional ship, called the ''Atlantic''. The main plotline revolves around a man who has a shipboard affair with a fellow passenger, which is eventually discovered by his wife. The ship also has aboard an elderly couple, the Rools, who are on their anniversary cruise. Midway across the Atlantic Ocean, the ''Atlantic'' strikes an [[iceberg]] and is damaged to the point where it is sinking into the Atlantic. A shortage of [[Lifeboat (shipboard)|lifeboat]]s causes the crew to only allow women and children in (though the captain allows a few men to take to the last remaining boats as the disaster reaches its zenith) and many couples are separated. Mrs. Rool refuses to leave her husband, and after the boats are gone all the passengers gather in the lounge and sing "[[Nearer, My God, to Thee]]" as the ''Atlantic'' sinks into the ocean. The final scenes depict a group of passengers saying the [[Lord's Prayer]] in a flooding lounge. The Lounge floods as the ship goes under water, and the lights go out.
''Atlantic'' is a drama film based on the sinking of the {{RMS|Titanic}} and set aboard a fictional ship, called the ''Atlantic''. The main plotline revolves around a man named Mr. Tate Hughes who has a shipboard affair with a fellow passenger, which is eventually discovered by his wife. The ship also has aboard an elderly couple, the Rools, who are on their anniversary cruise. Along with a priest, a young couple named Monica and Lawrence, and 3 middle aged Bachelors Dandy, Bowdey, and Pointer. Midway across the Atlantic Ocean, the ''Atlantic'' strikes an [[iceberg]] and is damaged to the point where it is sinking into the Atlantic. Lanchestor, one of the officers onboard confides in Mr. Rool that the ship is sinking. Mr. Rool slowly tells his friends. A shortage of [[Lifeboat (shipboard)|lifeboat]]s causes the crew to only allow women and children in (though the captain allows a few men to take to the last remaining boats as the disaster reaches its zenith) and many couples are separated. Mr. Tate Hughes feels remorse for his infadelity as Dandy feels hopelessness kick in while The Priest tries to comfort his friends. Mrs. Rool refuses to leave her husband despite his protests, and after the boats are gone all the passengers including The Rools, Mr. Tate Hughes, Dandy, Bowdey, and Pointer gather in the lounge and sing "[[Nearer, My God, to Thee]]" as a group of men play poker the ''Atlantic'' sinks into the ocean. The final scenes depict a group of passengers saying the [[Lord's Prayer]] in a flooding lounge lead by the priest. The Lounge floods as the ship goes under water, and the lights go out.

Where's the sealioning? What POV am I promoting? I even agreed to a compromise, while they initially took a defensive position and interpreted any answer I gave as bad faith. ===Evolution from Brahmi to Tocharian===
===Evolution from Brahmi to Tocharian===
[[File:2nd-century CE Sanskrit, Kizil China, Spitzer Manuscript folio 383 fragment verso.jpg|thumb|2nd-century CE Sanskrit, [[Kizil Caves]]. First line: "... [pa]kasah tasmad asma(d)vipaksapratipaksas..." . Spitzer, Manuscript folio 383 fragment.]]
[[File:2nd-century CE Sanskrit, Kizil China, Spitzer Manuscript folio 383 fragment verso.jpg|thumb|2nd-century CE Sanskrit, [[Kizil Caves]]. First line: "... [pa]kasah tasmad asma(d)vipaksapratipaksas..." . Spitzer, Manuscript folio 383 fragment.]]
Manuscripts in Sanskrit, using Middle [[Brahmi script]] and the Kushan period, and carbon dated to the 2nd century CE, have been discovered in the [[Tarim Basin]], and particularly at Kizil. Some of the fragments, quite possibly the oldest Sanskrit manuscript of any type related to Buddhism and Hinduism discovered so far, were discovered in 1906 in the form of a pile of more than 1,000 palm leaf fragments in the Ming-oi, [[Kizil Caves]], during the third Turfan expedition headed by [[Albert Grünwedel]]. The calibrated age of the manuscript by Carbon-14 technique is 130 CE (80–230 CE), corresponding to the rule of the Kushan king [[Kanishka]].
Manuscripts in Sanskrit, using [[Middle Brahmi]] script and the Kushan period, and carbon dated to the 2nd century CE, have been discovered in the [[Tarim Basin]], and particularly at Kizil. Some of the fragments, quite possibly the oldest Sanskrit manuscript of any type related to Buddhism and Hinduism discovered so far, were discovered in 1906 in the form of a pile of more than 1,000 palm leaf fragments in the Ming-oi, [[Kizil Caves]], during the third Turfan expedition headed by [[Albert Grünwedel]]. The calibrated age of the manuscript by Carbon-14 technique is 130 CE (80–230 CE), corresponding to the rule of the Kushan king [[Kanishka]].


The Tocharian script evolved from the [[Brahmi|Middle Brahmi]] script of the [[Kushan Empire]]:<ref>{{cite book |last1=Joshi |first1=R. In this case, A is the trustee, B is {{lang|xno|cestui que use}}, and C is the ''{{lang|xno|cestui que|italic=unset}} trust''. If B and C are the same person, which is often the case, the two terms will both refer to that same person. While common, a life-long duration is not essential; it can also last for a term of years, a shorter period, or for the life of another person.
In this case, A is the trustee, B is {{lang|xno|cestui que use}}, and C is the ''{{lang|xno|cestui que|italic=unset}} trust''. If B and C are the same person, which is often the case, the two terms will both refer to that same person. While common, a life-long duration is not essential; it can also last for a term of years, a shorter period, or for the life of another person.


While still used by some members of the judiciary and legal writers, ''cestui que'' and its derived terms have fallen out of everyday use in most modern legal parlance. In general trust law, it has largely been supplanted by the term [[beneficiary|''beneficiary'']] (where a sub-distinction is made: initial beneficiary and beneficiary in remainder).{{Citation needed|date=February 2026}}
While still used by some members of the judiciary and legal writers, ''cestui que'' and its derived terms have fallen out of everyday use in most modern legal parlance. In general trust law, it has largely been supplanted by the term [[beneficiary|''beneficiary'']] (where a similar sub-distinction is made: the life tenant and the beneficiary in remainder).{{Citation needed|date=February 2026}}

Security is a critical consideration in AI engineering, particularly as AI systems become increasingly integrated into sensitive and mission-critical applications. AI engineers implement robust security measures to protect models from adversarial attacks, such as evasion and [[Data poisoning|poisoning]], which can compromise system integrity and performance. Techniques such as adversarial training, where models are exposed to malicious inputs during development, help harden systems against these attacks.<ref>{{Cite book |last1=Fan |first1=Jiaxin |title=2022 7th IEEE International Conference on Data Science in Cyberspace (DSC) |last2=Yan |first2=Qi |last3=Li |first3=Mohan |last4=Qu |first4=Guanqun |last5=Xiao |first5=Yang |date=July 2022 |publisher=IEEE |isbn=978-1-6654-7480-1 |pages=48–55 |chapter=A Survey on Data Poisoning Attacks and Defenses |doi=10.1109/DSC55868.2022.00014 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Ren |first1=Kui |last2=Zheng |first2=Tianhang |last3=Qin |first3=Zhan |last4=[[Steve Liu|Liu, Xue]] |date=2020-03-01 |title=Adversarial Attacks and Defenses in Deep Learning |journal=Engineering |volume=6 |issue=3 |pages=346–360 |bibcode=2020Engin...6..346R |doi=10.1016/j.eng.2019.12.012 |issn=2095-8099|doi-access=free }}</ref>
Security is a critical consideration in AI engineering, particularly as AI systems become increasingly integrated into sensitive and mission-critical applications. AI engineers implement robust security measures to protect models from adversarial attacks, such as evasion and [[Data poisoning|poisoning]], which can compromise system integrity and performance. Techniques such as adversarial training, where models are exposed to malicious inputs during development, help harden systems against these attacks.<ref>{{Cite book |last1=Fan |first1=Jiaxin |title=2022 7th IEEE International Conference on Data Science in Cyberspace (DSC) |last2=Yan |first2=Qi |last3=Li |first3=Mohan |last4=Qu |first4=Guanqun |last5=Xiao |first5=Yang |date=July 2022 |publisher=IEEE |isbn=978-1-6654-7480-1 |pages=48–55 |chapter=A Survey on Data Poisoning Attacks and Defenses |doi=10.1109/DSC55868.2022.00014 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Ren |first1=Kui |last2=Zheng |first2=Tianhang |last3=Qin |first3=Zhan |last4=[[Steve Liu|Liu, Xue]] |date=2020-03-01 |title=Adversarial Attacks and Defenses in Deep Learning |journal=Engineering |volume=6 |issue=3 |pages=346–360 |bibcode=2020Engin...6..346R |doi=10.1016/j.eng.2019.12.012 |issn=2095-8099|doi-access=free }}</ref>


Additionally, securing the data used to train AI models is of paramount importance. [[Encryption]], secure data storage, and access control mechanisms are employed to safeguard sensitive information from unauthorized access and breaches. AI systems also require constant monitoring to detect and mitigate vulnerabilities that may arise post-deployment. In high-stakes environments like autonomous systems and healthcare, engineers incorporate redundancy and fail-safe mechanisms to ensure that AI models continue to function correctly in the presence of security threats.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-07-31 |title=How should we assess security and data minimisation in AI? |url=https://ico.org.uk/for-organisations/uk-gdpr-guidance-and-resources/artificial-intelligence/guidance-on-ai-and-data-protection/how-should-we-assess-security-and-data-minimisation-in-ai/ |access-date=2024-10-23 |website=ico.org.uk }}</ref>
Additionally, securing the data used to train AI models is of paramount importance. [[Encryption]], secure [[data storage]], and access control mechanisms are employed to safeguard sensitive information from unauthorized access and breaches. AI systems also require constant monitoring to detect and mitigate vulnerabilities that may arise post-deployment. In high-stakes environments like autonomous systems and healthcare, engineers incorporate redundancy and fail-safe mechanisms to ensure that AI models continue to function correctly in the presence of security threats.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-07-31 |title=How should we assess security and data minimisation in AI? |url=https://ico.org.uk/for-organisations/uk-gdpr-guidance-and-resources/artificial-intelligence/guidance-on-ai-and-data-protection/how-should-we-assess-security-and-data-minimisation-in-ai/ |access-date=2024-10-23 |website=ico.org.uk }}</ref>
